'''George "Mojo" Buford''' (November 10, 1929 – October 11, 2011) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player, best known for his work in [[Muddy Waters]]' band.

==Biography==
Buford relocated from [[Hernando, Mississippi]] to [[Memphis, Tennessee]] in his youth, where he studied the blues.<ref name="AMG"/> He relocated to [[Chicago]] in 1952,<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 96
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> forming the Savage Boys that eventually became known as the Muddy Waters, Jr. Band. They substituted for Muddy Waters at local nightclubs whilst he was touring.<ref name="AMG"/>

Buford first played in Muddy Waters' backing band in 1959, replacing [[Little Walter]], but in 1962 moved to [[Minneapolis]] to front his own band, and record albums.<ref name="AMG"/> It was in Minneapolis that Buford gained his nickname "Mojo", because of the audiences requesting him to perform his [[cover version]] of "[[Got My Mojo Working]]."<ref name="MS">{{cite web|url=http://www.mswritersandmusicians.com/musicians/george-mojo-buford.html |title=George Mojo Buford, a Mississippi musician |publisher=Mswritersandmusicians.com |date=1929-11-10 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>  Buford returned to Muddy Waters' combo in 1967 for a year when he replaced [[James Cotton]].<ref name="MS"/> He had a longer tenure with Muddy Waters in the early 1970s, and returned for the final time after [[Jerry Portnoy]] departed to form [[The Legendary Blues Band]].<ref name="AMG"/>

He also recorded for the Mr. Blues label (later re-issued on [[Rooster Blues]]), Blue Loon Records, and the British [[JSP Records|JSP]] label.<ref name="AMG"/>

Buford died on October 11, 2011, in Minneapolis, after a long hospitalization.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/george-mojo-buford-mn0000922782/biography |title=George "Mojo" Buford | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Amer">{{cite web |url=http://www.ameriblues.com/2011/10/11/mojo-buford-former-muddy-waters-harmonica-player-has-passed/ |title=Mojo Buford,  former Muddy Waters harmonica player, has passed |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Ameriblues.com |accessdate=October 11, 2011}}</ref>  He was 81.
